MULTITRANCHE FINANCING FACILITY AND INVESTMENT PROGRAM SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Republic of Kazakhstan 
   
Classification  Target classification: General intervention 
Sector: Transport and communications 
Subsector: Roads and highways  
Themes: Sustainable economic growth, capacity development, 
private sector development 
Subthemes: Fostering physical infrastructure development, 
institutional development, policy reforms 
   
Environment  The Investment Program is supported by safeguard frameworks 
Assessment  and by individual plans for individual tranches. The Investment 
Program  financed  by  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB),  its 
partner organizations, and the Government will be governed by 
the frameworks. The first tranche has been subjected to standard 
due diligence on environmental and social matters, and classified 
environmental category B. An initial environmental examination is 
summarized in Supplementary Appendix H. 
   
Program Description  Kazakhstan has put together a strategy or road map to develop 
the transport sector over the medium term. This covers all modes 
of transport, including national highways, as well as provincial and 
rural roads. The strategy recognizes the need for new assets (to 
increase network coverage) and repair and upkeep of existing 
ones (to extend their economic life and improve quality). Some of 
the  existing  assets  are  in  a  poor  state  of  repair.  A  policy 
framework  backs  the  road  sector  strategy.  It  embodies  basic 
operating principles and best practice approaches with regard to 
good governance and accountability, sustainable financing, policy 
and  regulatory  framework,  institutional  reform  and  capacity 
development,  road  safety,  road  sector  sustainability,  and  road 
transport operations. The strategy and the policy framework will 
be operationalized via an investment program combining “hard” 
and “soft” interventions over the short, medium, and long term. 
This program requires financing, and the financing strategy rests 
on  internal  and  external  sources.  ADB  and  several  other 
international financial institutions have been approached by the 
authorities to team up with the Government and private sector to 
provide such financing. 
 
The Road Development Program (RDP) covers 2006–2012. At 
the  start,  the  physical  investment  part  of  the  RDP  will  target 
national  roads,  the  backbone  of  the  network.  About 
7,000 kilometers (km) of these need major reconstruction and/or 
expansion. About 18,000 km of the network requires smaller scale 
rehabilitation works. About 18,000 km of local roads also require 
significant rehabilitation and expansion. Work on these roads will 
take  place  over  the  program  period,  although  the  main 
investments  will  be  undertaken  once  the  principal  network

ii   
deficiencies  are  addressed.  The  nonphysical  part  of  the  RDP 
covers institutional reforms and capacity building aimed at better 
planning, operations, fiduciary oversight and governance, project 
management,  reporting  and  results  measurement,  outsourcing, 
and private sector involvement.  
 
The physical and nonphysical parts of the Investment Program 
were identified on the basis of due diligence work or assessments 
conducted  over  recent  years—mostly  by  the  Government, 
although  some  in  conjunction  with  international  financial 
institutions. The  investment  and  advisory  services  components 
included under the Investment Program will be sequenced and 
split into sections before being “assigned” to individual financiers 
and the private sector.  
 
ADB will team up with the Islamic Development Bank (IDB) and 
the  Japan  International  Cooperation  Agency  (JICA)  to  handle 
sections of the road network in the southern part of the country. 
These  sections  amounting  to  480  km  is  part  of  the  so-called 
Western  Europe–Western  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC) 
International  Transit  Corridor.  The  overall  investment  for  the 
corridor is about $6.7 billion, of which the ADB section and that of 
its partners amount to about $1.48 billion. Other financiers behind 
the overall corridor development plan include the Government, the 
private  sector,  the  World  Bank,  and  European  Bank  for 
Reconstruction and Development. ADB has been requested to 
provide $700 million toward the Investment Program through a 
multitranche financing facility (MFF). IDB will provide $414 million 
and JICA $150 million. 
   
Rationale  The road sector has long-standing operational and institutional 
bottlenecks: (i) the network is incomplete, and in some sections in 
bad condition; (ii) truck overloading is frequent, cutting into the 
economic life of road assets; (iii) revenues from transit are low, 
affecting  cost  recovery  and  reinvestment  capabilities; 
(iv) inefficient  cross-border  procedures  increase  the  burden  on 
trade and traders, and raise the cost of doing business; (v) weak 
road sector planning affects sound investment sequencing; and 
(vi) project development and project management shortcomings 
create inefficiencies, high costs, and bad governance. These gaps 
translate  into  higher-than-average  transport  costs.  They  also 
hamper regional cooperation and integration opportunities, and 
ultimately the country’s competitiveness. The Investment Program 
and  the  proposed  financing  are  intended  to  remove  these 
constraints. A problem tree analysis is in Appendix 2. 
 
Investment Program  The  Investment  Program  caters  for  the  improvement  and 
expansion  of  the  Western  Europe–Western  PRC  International 
Transit Corridor. This runs from Khorgos at the border with the 
PRC, through Almaty and Shymkent, to the western border with 
the  Russian  Federation.  This  corridor  is  underpinned  by  road

iii     
investments made in the PRC, Kyrgyz Republic, and Tajikistan. In 
this sense, the corridor is an integral part and flagship transaction 
under the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) 
program. Further, the corridor paves the way and justifies the 
development  of  the  North–South  Corridor  which  runs  into 
Uzbekistan,  Turkmenistan,  Afghanistan,  and  Pakistan.  Each  of 
these corridors will be backed by work at the national level on 
rural access roads.   
 
A  landmark  reform  is  already  in  place,  related  to  the 
reorganization of the Ministry of Transport and Communications 
(MOTC). This involves the separation of key business functions—
procurement,  financial  management,  contract  supervision,  and 
quality control. As a result, MOTC is becoming a facilitator rather 
than a “doer”. Most road works contracts are already outsourced 
to the private sector. The exception is routine maintenance works 
that  are  outsourced  to  a  state-owned  road  maintenance 
enterprise—although even here there are moves to bring in the 
private  sector  under  a  variety  of  revenue  and  risk  sharing 
arrangements—an  approach  followed  successfully  in  several 
European  Union  countries.  Another  feature  of  the  institutional 
reform  program  already  in  place  is  the  establishment  of  a 
Committee  of  Roads  under  MOTC;  and  the  introduction  of  a 
warranty system for construction, operation, and maintenance. In 
addition,  the  procurement  process  has  been  overhauled  and 
prescribed in all bid documentation schedules. MOTC has also 
established  a  quality  control  section  and  oblast-based  road 
construction testing laboratories. These changes will yield positive 
results  over  the  short  term,  but  more  are  needed.  The  most 
important  changes  concern  the  establishment  of  a  road  fund; 
improved planning and project management; refinement of the 
legal framework over time (e.g. to facilitate build-operate-transfer 
and concessions, and improved financial management systems); 
the introduction of tougher road safety systems; and staff training.  
 
The Investment Program earmarked for the three institutions and 
the Government is divided into three projects financed under three 
separate tranches. The first tranche under the ADB financing will 
have two major components: (i) road development, and (ii) road 
operations and maintenance.

MFF Modality   The MFF is proposed as the modality to extend ADB financing to 
the  Investment  Program.  This  proposal  is  qualified  on  five 
grounds. First, the modality provides flexibility to the Government. 
Within  the  proposed  maximum  financing  commitment  of  $700 
million, ADB and the Government can easily modify the amount 
and  timing  of  ADB  contributions  under  each  tranche.  This  is 
important in case the government can raise additional financing 
from other sources (such as the private sector). The other element 
behind this flexibility is that the financing to be provided by ADB 
can be closely linked to the availability of resources within ADB (a 
matter made clear to the authorities), as well as to compliance 
with undertakings made under a financing framework agreement.  
 
Second, financing under the MFF can be linked with technical, 
safeguards,  legal  and  other  project  readiness  filters.  The 
authorities can make specific loan conversions under the broad 
facility when projects are ready for implementation. This approach 
facilitates advance actions, including documentation preparation 
and the establishment of relevant administrative arrangements. 
The MFF also allows ADB, the Government, and its partners to 
link  more  closely  the  financing  to  changes  in  the  cost  of 
subprojects bundled under each tranche. This avoids problems 
associated with cost overruns. Third, the MFF modality allows 
ADB to enter into a medium-term partnership with the authorities 
and its cofinancing partners, and in the process create stability but 
also credibility at the level of the financing plan. The MFF also 
mixes the physical investments with advisory services. The latter 
includes work on capacity and policy actions, which at times could 
be precursors to making the actual physical investments.  
 
Fourth, the individual contract packages are large in size and 
limited in number. This invalidates a sector loan approach, as well 
as  stand-alone  project  modalities,  as  alternatives.  Although  in 
theory any of these modalities could be used, the efficiency gains 
would not be the same. Fifth, all the conditions precedents for the 
use of an MFF are in place—there is a strategic context, road

map, policy framework, investment program, and financing plan.  
 
The  channeling  of  funding  via  an  MFF  provides  ADB,  the 
Government, and the cofinanciers with a chance to shift time and 
resources  away  from  repetitive  processing  tasks  during  the 
network development period into implementation support and key 
advisory  services.  The  modality  moves  the  analytical  work  up 
front, leaving resources and multi-entry points for ADB and its 
partners to focus on implementation, capacity, and reforms. ADB 
and its partners have agreed decision-making criteria and filters 
for  the  provision  of  finance,  including  specific  warranties  and 
representations  and  covenants  leading  to  suspension  and 
cancellation of financing.     
   
Impact and Outcome  The  expected  impact  of  the  Investment  Program  will  be 
sustainable economic development as a result of the expected 
outcome  of  an  efficient  transport  system  in  Zhambyl  Oblast. 
Design and monitoring frameworks have been prepared for the 
overall corridor development plan and for the Investment Program 
including the first tranche. These results are linked to the problem 
tree analysis. The frameworks are in Appendix 1.   
   
Financing Conditions  The MFF will be split into three tranches. ADB financing will be 
provided from ADB’s ordinary capital resources. The maximum 
amount  of  ADB  financing  under  the  MFF  will  be  $700  million 
equivalent. The terms of ADB financing will follow the provisions 
of the ordinary operations loan regulations applicable to London 
interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based  loans,  subject  to 
modifications  that  may  be  included  under  individual  loan 
agreements.

Implementation Plan  The transaction team has prepared a project implementation plan, 
by  linking  each  of  the  main  tasks  under  the  first  tranche  to 
projected  individual  contracts  for  goods,  works,  and  services. 
There is also a higher level implementation plan for the MFF as a 
whole.  The  idea  behind  this  plan  is  to  demonstrate  project 
readiness, but also to agree project management actions ahead of 
ADB’s Board of Directors consideration date of the Report and 
Recommendations of the President. This approach facilitates the 
work of a team made up of ADB and MOTC. The “cool-off” period 
between Board approval and loan signing date will be used to 
establish the MOTC’s team, agree a final organizational structure, 
define the final team skills mix, and seek administrative and legal 
approvals.  
 
The  anchor  for  the  implementation  plan  is  a  management 
information  system  connecting  the  civil  works  contractor 
responsibilities,  tasks,  and  time  schedules  to  those  of  the 
supervision  consultants,  the  local  program  management  office 
team, and the ADB staff in charge of program oversight. The 
information system will record contract awards and disbursement 
projections and anticipated dates for actions by the contractor, 
executing agency team, and ADB. It will also provide a summary 
of  the  reports  due  for  management  and  financiers.  The 
implementation plan for the Investment Program is summarized in 
Appendix 9. Supplementary Appendix B contains more details on 
this plan.  
   
Procurement  Procurement of goods, civil works, and related services financed 
from the ADB and JICA loans will be done in accordance with 
ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to 
time). International competitive bidding (ICB) contract packages 
will be used for civil works over $3 million and goods over $1 
million.  National  competitive  bidding  for  civil  works  could  be 
conducted  for  contracts  not  exceeding  $3  million.  Civil  works 
contracts  will  be  procured  through  ICB  among  pre-qualified 
bidders. ADB’s prior review procedures will be followed.  
 
Tranche 1 involves three ICB contract packages for civil works.  
   
Consulting Services  The Investment Program requires the assistance of consultants. 
The  assistance  is  split  into  two:  a  core  team  to  be  engaged 
upfront and additional inputs to be brought into the Investment 
Program as and when required. The first will be financed under 
the first tranche and the latter under subsequent tranches.  Under 
tranche 1, ADB financing will be used to engage the services of 
international and national experts. About 814 person-months of 
consultancy services have been budgeted for this purpose. These 
include 179 person-months international and 635 person-months 
of national staff. The actual team composition and skill mix may 
vary  during  various  project  implementation  phases.  The  same 
applies to the terms of reference and profile of the experts. The

viii  
general principle is that advisers will be secured on a competitive 
basis and that the specific mandates will be defined and finalized 
by  the  management  team  responsible  for  the  Investment 
Program. ADB will be required to approve the selection process.  
 
All  consultants  financed  from  ADB  and  JICA  loans  will  be 
recruited  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants  (2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  the 
procurement  plans  for  the  projects.  Consulting  firms  will  be 
selected  and  engaged  using  ADB’s  quality-  and  cost-based 
selection procedures. Full technical proposals will be required for 
all consulting services. 
 
   
Benefits and  The  Investment  Program  will  benefit  an  array  of  people  and 
Beneficiaries  business  in  Kazakhstan  and  neighboring  countries.  The  main 
benefits  revolve  around  better,  safer,  cheaper,  and  faster 
connectivity. Better connectivity can yield important externalities, 
including access to health and education centers. The program 
will have gender-related benefits, particularly as urban centers 
become better connected to isolated rural areas, thus improving 
mobility  and  job  opportunities  in  the  city.  There  are  also 
institutional  and  change  management  gains.  The  beneficiaries 
include  trading,  logistics  and  other  service  industry  operators. 
They  also  include  farmer  communities,  food  and  industrial 
manufacturers, wholesalers, and retailers. The economic internal 
rate of return for the Investment Program is 18%.   
   
Risks and Assumptions  Sound,  timely,  and  cost-effective  implementation  of  the 
Investment  Program  assumes  a  professional  and  competent 
project management function, an unaltered strategy and policy 
framework,  and  continued  institutional  changes.  Exogenous 
factors, such as rising construction costs caused by fuel price 
increases,  may  also  have  a  bearing  on  the  success  of  the 
program, especially with regard to the overall budget and current 
financing plan. Finally, and after construction, the success of the 
program will depend on how well and how frequently the assets 
are maintained. The introduction of best practice safety measures 
is also a matter for consideration. 
 
Overall, the chances that implementation will be done on time and 
within  budget,  and  meet  international  standards  are  high.  The 
project management team will be staffed with skilled personnel, 
national  and  international.  An  experienced  professional  with  a 
record  in  project  management  will  manage  this  team.  The 
business processes and the operating procedures for awarding 
contracts  and  then  managing  them  are  reasonably  well 
established and credible in Kazakhstan. It is also highly likely that 
the  Committee  of  Roads  will  adhere  to  best  practice  when  it 
comes to design and construction standards. Project management 
will be tightened and then monitored through the introduction of a 
high  standard  road  construction  management  and  information

ix     
system to ensure compliance with ADB operating policies and 
procedures,  including  those  related  to  financial  management, 
anticorruption measures, procurement, and safeguards. 
 
The  Government  has  committed  to  the  strategy  and  policy 
framework.  The  policy  framework  has  all  the  right  principles, 
including  outsourcing  to  the  private  sector  and  regular  road 
maintenance funding. The risk of a policy reversal is low. The 
same applies to the roles and functions of key institutions. MOTC 
has  been  restructured  and  given  more  of  a  regulatory  and 
supervision  mandate.  It  is  unlikely  that  this  institution  will  be 
reconverted to operate the construction and operation of the entire 
road network on its own. Maintenance remains in public hands. 
One of the key reforms includes the possible reintroduction of a 
road maintenance fund. This will assure continuity and stability 
with regard to the financing plan after the construction phase.  
 
The Government is also assumed to continue improving cross-
border policies and facilities, and sustaining policies conducive to 
economic growth and regional integration. Training will be given 
under tranche 1 to take care of capacity building needs.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.   I submit, for your approval, the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
multitranche financing facility (MFF) to the Republic of Kazakhstan for the Central Asia Regional 
Economic  Cooperation  (CAREC)  Transport  Corridor  I  (Zhambyl  Oblast  Section)  [Western 
Europe–Western People’s Republic of China International Transit Corridor] Investment Program 
(the Investment Program), and (ii) an administration by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) of a 
loan to the Republic of Kazakhstan for the Investment Program to be provided by the Japan 
International Cooperation Agency (JICA). The design and monitoring framework (DMF) for the 
Investment Program is in Appendix 1.1  
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
2.   The economy of Kazakhstan has grown rapidly because of increased prices on its 
leading exports such as oil, metals, and grain. Gross domestic product (GDP) growth has 
reached about 10.6% annually since 2001.2 This growth is expected to continue, albeit with 
possible blips during the short term on account of current external shocks and international 
financial crisis. In any event, strong economic growth will lead to an increase in road freight 
transport (in ton-kilometers) of about 10% per year and a rise in the number of vehicles of about 
5% per year.3 The motorization level of about 100 cars per 1,000 population is relatively high in 
the region but low by the European standard of above 300 cars per 1,000 inhabitants.4 
 
3.   Kazakhstan’s  vast  territory,  low  density  of  population,  mineral  resources  scattered 
across the country, and location between Europe and Asia make it one of the world’s most 
cargo-intensive systems. This results in high dependency on the transport system.  
 
4.   Roads are a key element of Kazakhstan’s transport system. They play an important role 
in  providing  access  to  rural  areas,  and  facilitating  transit  traffic  and  in-country  transport 
movement.  However,  much  of  the  road  network  is  in  poor  condition—about  60%  of  the 
republican (national) roads require major rehabilitation and proper maintenance. Moreover, the 
feeder road network serving the rural population is not fully developed; and is characterized by 
poor conditions and a low service level, especially during wintertime. This results in a high cost 
of goods—the transport cost component is about 10% of the cargo value, which is far above the 
average of about 4% in developed economies (footnote 2).

governments and their respective road organizations: (i) the republican roads are under the 
responsibility of the Ministry of Transport and Communications (MOTC) and managed by the 
Committee of Roads, (ii) local or rural roads are under oblasts or provincial governments, and 
(iii) urban roads are under municipality or city authorities. There are about 23,000 kilometers 
(km) of republican roads, of which only about 40% has an asphalt-based surface; and about

7.   The Government has recognized the transport deficiencies and is planning to increase

about 1% of GDP on their roads. As expected, countries with road funds spend more—an 
average of about 1.6% of GDP, of which about 0.3% is spent on road maintenance. The current

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
1.  Road Sector Road Map 
a.  Strategic Objectives and Approach 
 
8.   Kazakhstan  has  developed  a  transport  sector  strategy  (the  Transport  Strategy)  to 
improve and expand the network over the short to medium term.5 The Transport Strategy 
including a strategy for the road sector outlines several objectives and sets out quantitative and 
qualitative targets and operating principles. The underlying theme is to make the road system 
larger, better, more accessible, more affordable, more efficient, safer, and more environmentally 
friendly. The Government also wants to see greater integration between different modes, cost 
recovery, much more outsourcing to the private sector – construction, maintenance, operations, 
and management. The Transport Strategy calls for investments in “hard” infrastructure, as well 
as for institutional effectiveness and change.  This includes streamlining the mandate of the 
Ministry of Transport and Communications (MOTC); improving planning, governance, financial 
and project management, safeguards standards, and road safety measures. The Transport 
Strategy sequences priority investments splitting them into public and private investments and a 
mix of both. These create the conditions for investments (the level playing field for public and 
private actions), but also the criteria for operating assets and monitoring performance and 
results.

medium term (Appendix 3). A first set of principles under this framework includes institutional 
performance and accountability, system efficiency, cost recovery, transparency and controls for 
the way financial resources are used and managed, competition with regard to bidding for 
contracts (of all types), fiduciary oversight, and cost effectiveness. A second set of principles

    c.  Challenges 
 
10.   The development of the road system faces challenges.  The due diligence process for 
the Investment Program identified several issues related to (i) the road network (coverage, 
quality and accessibility periods); (ii) the road sector institutions; and (iii) the level of finance 
available for investments. A problem tree analysis shows the main issues by category. The 
object with this work is to separate the root causes of the problem from their symptoms. This 
problem tree is linked to the DMF for the Investment Program. The objective shown in the 
problem tree relates to the impact shown in the DMF; the core problem to the outcome and the 
causes of the problem to the outputs.  The solution chosen relates to the inputs shown in the 
DMF.   
 
(i)  Road  network  coverage.  The  Republican  road  network  offers  reasonable 
coverage compared with the rural and urban roads, albeit with still important 
missing links. Substantial investments are needed to make it complete and more 
effective. The rural road network is the most limited of the three.6 This will be part 
of another investment program at a later stage. The first priority now is to deal 
with the national road network – while repairing several provincial roads at the 
same time.  
 
(ii)  Quality of existing assets. Major sections of the Republican, rural and urban 
networks are in a poor state of repair. MOTC wants to covert 86% of republican 
roads and 70% of local roads into a “good condition” by 2013, up from 62% 
(republican  roads)  and  51%  (rural  roads)  in  2006.  Only  about  40%  of  the 
republican roads are asphalt-based.  
 
(iii)  Access. Parts of the road network are impassable during winter months. This 
makes access to rural areas, towns and neighboring countries difficult, thereby 
affecting trade flows and competitiveness.  
 
(iv)  Institutional/management  gaps.  MOTC  has  already  undergone  reforms 
recently and is becoming efficient, both in planning and monitoring. But more 
reforms are needed.  The oblast administrations are less capable and need 
technical back up.  Unless addressed, this gap affects rural and provincial road 
network development.  Institutional gaps are aggravated by lack of experience in

(vi)  Strategy and policy framework.  Until recently, the Transport Strategy was

Both gaps have been taken care of, resulting in a more coherent investment

(vii)  Road safety. While nation-wide data indicates that road conditions improved in 
2007, the number of people killed every year exceeds 2,000, with a further 4,700 
injured. A fatality rate of 18 per 100,000 inhabitants was reported in 2004, higher 
than the regional average. The number of people killed between 2005 and 2007 
increased by more than 19%. Road safety has been too downplayed. Speeding 
is  key  contributor,  but  low  quality  construction,  the  lack  of  security  barriers, 
lighting, and police oversight are also to blame. The same applies to vehicle 
roadworthiness  standards  and  supervision.  The  Ministry  of  Internal  Security, 
responsible for dealing with road accidents, has devised a program to deal with 
these  problems.  Past  efforts  to  establish  a  Road  Safety  Commission  were 
resisted. This concept is now widely accepted and will be reconsidered.    
 
(viii)  Border crossing times. The main transport routes in Kazakhstan are into the 
Russian Federation, Europe, and Central Asia. A total of 24,000 commercial 
transit  vehicles,  including  large  buses  and  medium  to  large  trucks,  cross 
Kazakhstan every day in 2007. A total of about 350,000 tons of transit traffic pass 
through  this  route.  Business  volumes  are  growing  fast.  This  puts  increasing 
pressure  on  the  road  network.  Without  appropriate  and  corresponding 
investments at customs points, cross-border time delays and costs are become a 
burden  on  business.  Operators  already  complain  of  unreasonable  delays, 
complicated procedures, too many frontier inspections, contradictions between 
domestic  transport  legislation  and  international  standards,  and  the  lack  of 
international standards and agreements relating to transit and traffic regulation. 
Although  there  have  been  improvements  in  all  these  areas  in  recent  times, 
border crossing continues to be a problem to trade. 
 
(ix)  Road operations. Road operations and traffic management requires reliable and 
accurate data on all aspects of the network. Kazakhstan has problems on this

front.  Advance early warning information systems do not exist. But these are 
necessary to handle axle load monitoring and controls.  There is also a need for 
road weather information, highways advisory radio and electronic signs, and 
traffic recordings. This information is also useful for maintenance managers. This 
includes making the right winter road maintenance decisions - to ensure that 
road restrictions are minimized and costs are kept low. 
 
(x)  Road data and planning. Road and traffic data are unreliable, out of date and 
incomplete. But planning also needs tightening. The 7-year development plans 
are  based  on  norms  rather  than  analytical  information  regarding  system

    d.  Road Development Program 
11.   MOTC  has  defined  a  road  development  program  for  the  medium  term  –  Road

Cash outlays are also divided into capital expenditures - for the development of new assets and

12.   Physical Investment.  The capital expenditure budget for this has gone up steadily

2.  Preconditions for a Multitranche Financing Facility Modality 
17.   The  MFF  is  proposed  as  the  modality  to  extend  ADB  financing  to  the  Investment 
Program. This proposal is qualified on five grounds. First, the modality provides flexibility to the 
Government. ADB and the Government can easily modify the amount and timing of ADB 
contributions under each tranche. This is important in case the Government can raise additional 
financing from other sources (such as the private sector), or if the Government needs more time 
to finalize their own financing packages (documentation, etc.). The other element behind this 
flexibility is that the financing to be provided by ADB can be closely linked to the availability of 
resources within ADB (a matter made clear to the Government), as well as to compliance with 
warranties and representations made under a framework financing agreement (FFA). 
 
18.   Second, financing under the MFF can be linked to technical, safeguards, legal, and other 
project readiness filters. The authorities can make specific loan conversions under the broad 
facility  when  projects  are  ready  for  execution.  This  approach  facilitates  advance  actions, 
including  documentation  preparation  and  the  establishment  of  relevant  administrative 
arrangements. The MFF also allows ADB, the Government, and its partners to link the financing 
more closely to changes in the cost of projects bundled under each tranche. This avoids 
problems associated with cost overruns. Third, the MFF modality allows ADB to enter into a 
medium-term partnership with the Government and its cofinancing partners, and in the process 
create stability but also credibility at the level of the financing plan. The MFF also mixes the 
physical investments with advisory services. The latter includes financing to advance work on 
capacity and policy actions, which at times could be precursors to making the actual physical 
investments. 
 
19.   Fourth, the individual contract packages are large in size and limited in number. This 
invalidates a sector loan approach, as well as stand-alone project modalities, as alternatives. 
Although in theory any of these modalities could be used, the efficiency gains would not be the 
same. Fifth, all the conditions precedents for the use of an MFF are in place—there is a 
strategic context, road map, policy framework, investment program, and financing plan. The 
channeling of funding via an MFF provides ADB, the Government, and cofinanciers with a 
chance to shift time and resources away from repetitive processing tasks during the network 
development  period  into  implementation  support  and  key  advisory  services.  The  modality 
moves the analytical work up front, leaving resources and multi-entry points for ADB and its 
partners to focus on execution, capacity, and reforms. ADB and its partners have agreed 
decision-making criteria and filters for the provision of finance, including specific warranties and 
representations and covenants leading to suspension and cancellation of financing. 
 
    a.  Strategic Context and Strategy 
20.   The Government wants to develop the transport system as a whole and has a clear 
strategy for one of its components—the road sector. The aim is remove existing bottlenecks in 
the way of better connectivity, competition and trade. As is the case elsewhere in the region, 
these obstacles are physical, institutional, and policy in nature. The magnitude of the problem 
was worked out through various specialized studies. These gave way to the preparation of a 
strategy  with  quantitative  and  qualitative  targets.  The  quantitative  target  is  to  develop  14 
strategic  road  corridors,  6  of  which  are  international  roads.  The  qualitative  targets  are

institutional improvements, policy refinements, best practice on construction and maintenance 
and efficient financing.  The strategy calls for a mix of interventions over the short, medium and 
long term, further split between different types of networks – republican, provincial, and rural.  
The republican network is the first priority:   
 
(i)  Uzbekistan Border–Shymkent–Taraz–Almaty–Khorgos–PRC Border,  
(ii)  Shymkent–Kyzylorda–Aktobe–Uralsk–Samara,  
(iii)  Almaty–Karaganda–Astana–Petropavlovsk–Russian Border,  
(iv)  Russian Border–Astrakhan–Atyrau–Aktau–Turkmenistan Border, 
(v)  Omsk–Pavlodar–Semipalatinsk–Mykapchagai–PRC Border, and 
(vi)  Astana–Kostanai–Russian Border. 
 
21.   The Transport Strategy recognizes the difference between the creation of new assets 
and reconstruction, rehabilitation, and repair of old ones. Investments will be both public sector 
and public/private in nature. The road concession law was amended in 2008 to better attract 
private investments. The road sector financing mostly relies on three main sources of funds: the 
national  budget,  the  private  sector  (national  and  international),  and  international  financing 
institutions such as ADB. A road fund was in place several years ago to deal with recurrent 
financing, but was abolished. The roadmap or strategy for the sector fits well with ADB’s own 
core business areas. Transport is one of the main activities under the Long Term Strategic 
Framework. Within the ADB’s Central and West Asia Department, transport and logistics are 
priorities  for  most  countries,  including  Kazakhstan.  This  strategy  is  articulated  and 
operationalized  via  financing  and  advice  for  projects  with  national  and  regional  content. 
Regional activities fall within the mandate of CAREC. CAREC stands for connectivity, improved 
competitiveness, cooperation and integration, mainly via investments in transport, energy and 
trade  facilitation  and  targeted  advice  on  these  sectors,  regional  public  goods  and  special 
themes such as capacity building and the environment.

    e.  Rationale 
26.    The DMF splits the results into outputs, outcome, and impact. These are related to the 
problem tree analysis, which highlights the objective of the Investment Program (impact), the 
nature of the core problem (outcome), and the causes of the problem (outputs). The core 
problem  can  be  described  as  follows.  The  road  network  (national,  rural,  and  urban)  is 
incomplete and in bad shape. Some parts of the network are impassable during some times of 
the year (continuity of service). Such situation needs redressing to ensure that the country and 
the region has a transport system that increases connectivity (within the country and with the 
outside world), competitiveness (lower transport costs), efficiency (shorter travel time), safety 
(lower fatalities), and trade and regional cooperation.  
 
27.   In  terms  of  non-physical  issues,  the  institutional  effectiveness  is  low,  the  planning 
capability  limited,  the  organizational  structure  complex,  and  the  project  management  skills 
deficient.    MOTC  has  also  been  short  of  funds.  These  issues  are  aggravated  by  poor 
management and information systems and weak policies and procedures related to themes

such  as  safeguards  and  financial  management.  The  objective  of  the  Investment  Program 
therefore is to address these problems.  As a result, global and specific benefits accruing to 
communities in the country and the region are expected.

IV.  BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Benefits  
1.  Economic Benefits 
66.   The improved Investment Program road will permit higher travel speeds, shorten travel 
distance, and improve the road safety standard. As a result, vehicle operating costs and travel 
time for users of the improved road will be reduced. The accident rate is also expected to 
decline. The economic analysis for the road sections in Zhambyl Oblast indicates an average 
economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  of  18%  showing  that  the  Investment  Program  is 
economically viable. The summary of the economic analysis is in Appendix 14. 
 
67.   Project 1 was found to achieve a combined EIRR of 28%. A sensitivity test was carried 
out to assess the impact of different benefit and cost attributes for Project 1. Under the worst 
case scenario, with traffic 25% less and construction costs increased by 25%, the sensitivity test 
demonstrated  that  Project  1  is  robust  across  the  broad  range  of  variations  in  these  key 
parameters with EIRR of about 20%. Moreover, the combined effect of excluding generated 
traffic and ignoring traffic accident savings resulted in an EIRR of about 26%. 
 
68.   A sensitivity test was also performed to examine the effect of delaying implementation of 
Project 1 to 5 years. The EIRR was slightly reduced from 28% to 27%. This suggests that, 
despite the effect of reducing the discounted construction costs by deferring construction over 
5 years, the overall effect is negative—with reduced net present value and rates of return for all 
sensitivity tests. This sensitivity test further demonstrates that the results for Project 1 are robust 
across the broad range of variations in these key parameters. 
 
2.  Economic Impacts 
69.   Analysis was undertaken using a forward-looking computable general equilibrium model 
to estimate direct and indirect effects of the corridor development plan. A summary of the 
macroeconomic assessment is in Appendix 15. This approach captures not only direct costs 
and benefits, but a wide array of economic activities that are facilitated by infrastructure through 
transport and distribution services. Generally, the cumulative indirect benefits far outweigh direct 
project  costs  and  benefits,  and  these  benefits  accrue  both  to  Kazakhstan  and  to  many 
economies linked to it by trade—including neighboring Central Asian countries as well as more 
remote trading partners such as European Union countries. Because of their pervasive linkages, 
more efficient trade and transport services benefit every sector of Kazakhstan’s economy. By 
2020, the indirect benefits of the road corridor will be more than 10 times the direct project net 
benefits. 
 
70.   The corridor investment will have significant regional spillovers for Kazakhstan’s trading 
partners, including above all the Central Asian economies whose combined GDP will be 43%

20   
higher  in  2020  compared  to  the  2010  benchmark.  The  effect  is  greatest  for  immediate 
neighbors, like the Kyrgyz Republic, which have high trade shares with and through Kazakhstan 
and relatively low initial GDP. These growth spillovers can be expected to radiate across the 
region and beyond, and are an important justification for this Investment Program in the regional 
policy dialogue. Despite their size and diversity, both the Russian Federation and the PRC will 
gain significantly from the entire corridor investment through trade linkages, with real GDP gains 
of 4% for the Russian Federation in 2020 and 6% for the PRC. 
 
71.   It is important to recognize the stakes that all Kazakhstan’s trading partners have in 
regional infrastructure. While the percentage effects of real GDP results in level terms vary with 
proximity, level effects depend on the volume of trade and size (capacity for export production 
and import absorption) of trading partners. Thus, the economies of European Union countries, 
for example, capture significant nominal benefits from the improved transport infrastructure 
because of strong ties to the region through capital goods markets and relatively high import 
and export elasticities. These results support the essential message that the benefits of this 
Investment Program are truly multilateral. Significant nominal income gains accrue to larger 
economies, suggesting a broader basis for financing and policy support. 
 
3.  Sustainability 
72.   The Investment Program will be fully public sector investment, as the current traffic of 
about 4,000 vehicles per day does not justify full private sector investment. However, MOTC will 
consider offering the Investment Program to the private sector at a later stage when traffic 
justifies  doing  so.  With  EBRD  assistance,  MOTC  is  developing  a  concession  agreement 
between the Government and the private sector; and is piloting public–private partnership for a 
road section of the corridor. Provided this pilot project is implemented successfully, it can be 
replicated in other highway sections. 
 
73.   The road sector budget will increase up to about 1.6% of GDP by 2012, of which routine 
maintenance will be about 0.1% GDP. It is expected that the routine maintenance will also 
increase—reaching 0.3% of GDP—to keep the Investment Program sustainable. 
 
4.  Governance 
74.   A governance assessment was undertaken for the corridor investment by the World 
Bank. ADB confirmed the methodology and findings, and the supports the recommendations. 
Based on the analysis of the legislative framework, the effectiveness of regulatory institutions, 
the strength of enforcement regimes, the capacity of the Committee of Roads and MOTC, the 
availability of human resources, and the risk of corruption, the fiduciary assessment rated the 
environment for conducting procurement under the Investment Program as “high risk”.15 To 
mitigate this, it was agreed that the procurement activities will be delegated to the PMC teams. 
Moreover, a financial management action plan and an anticorruption action were developed. 
The governance assessment is in Supplementary Appendix E.  
 
5.  Social Dimensions and Poverty Reduction  
75.   The Investment Program is a general intervention, as opposed to a targeted intervention 
that specifically addresses poverty reduction through interventions at the level of households, 
specific  services,  or  geographical  determinants  of  poverty.  Consequently,  the  Investment 
Program design does not have to include a poverty reduction strategy.

76.   There will be both direct and indirect beneficiaries of the Investment Program, both in 
Kazakhstan and in neighboring countries. The beneficiaries include trading, logistics, and other 
service  industry  operators.  They  also  include  farmer  communities,  food  and  industrial 
manufacturers, wholesalers, and retailers. The summary poverty reduction and social strategy is 
in Appendix 16 and the poverty and social analysis is in Supplementary Appendix F.  
 
77.   The  Investment  Program  is  expected  to  generate  considerable  local  employment, 
particularly for unskilled labor. Opportunities will vary along the alignment of the Investment 
Program roads. The Investment Program is not expected to exacerbate gender inequities. 
Better connectivity can yield important externalities, including access to health and education 
centers. The program will have gender-related benefits, particularly as urban centers become 
better connected to isolated rural areas, thus improving mobility and job opportunities in the city. 
There are also institutional and change management gains. Opportunities are to be expected 
along much of the alignment, although female participation may be limited where worker camps 
are established, unless the contractors make special provisions available to attract women to 
the sites. Highway construction and the development of long-term transit routes will likely lead to 
an increase in the transmission and spread of HIV in many areas. Public information leaflets 
focusing on HIV/AIDS transmission, and initiated a needle exchange program at one site will be 
distributed. These initiatives, and others, will be incorporated in the Investment Program. 
 
78.   Kazakhstan  is  a  source,  transit,  and  destination  country  for  human  trafficking;  and 
evidence of internal rural–urban trafficking is growing. The Investment Program is not likely to 
affect current trafficking patterns materially, as the investments themselves will not remove any 
significant transit barriers. However, once work on the full corridor is completed, including 
Zhambyl Oblast, the improved corridor may be seen by both human and drug traffickers as an 
attractive alternative to the prevailing south–north route. To deter such a transition, one element 
of the communications program for the whole corridor program should focus on human and drug 
trafficking, aimed at raising public awareness and encouraging civil society engagement to 
protect potential victims of trafficking and aid efforts to detect and stop traffickers.

2.  Environmental Impacts and Mitigation Measures 
82.   Project 1 will have no new impacts on the natural environment along or inside of the 
ROW, aside from the possible need to remove a few shelterbelt trees. All attempts should be 
made to minimize removal of shelterbelt trees, as there are few trees in the area to provide 
shade, bird nesting sites, and wildlife habitat. MOTC is expected to pay special attention to the 
following potential impacts during construction: mismanagement of earthwork and aggregate 
site operations, mismanagement of lead contaminated soils, mismanagement of construction 
camp wastes and fuels, mismanagement of asphalt and concrete production, air pollution during 
construction, and bridge and culvert replacement and repair. The Investment Program will also 
enhance the capacity of the EA on environmental management through training provided by the 
PMC-WB. 
 
83.   Project 1 has no major environmental impacts and according to ADB guidelines is 
environment category B. An initial environmental examination (IEE) and summary IEE (SIEE) 
have  been  prepared.  The  SIEE  is  in  Supplementary  Appendix  H  and  the  IEE  is  in 
Supplementary Appendix I. Project implementation will require environmental monitoring as 
detailed in the environmental management plan (EMP) included in the IEE and SIEE to avoid 
standard construction impacts. These include environmental standard operating procedures 
such as cleaning up construction sites, proper disposal of spoils, grading damaged land and 
replanting  vegetation,  and  protecting  the  public  from  excessive  noise  and  dust  during 
construction.   
 
84.   The EARF has been prepared to provide guidance in preparation of environmental 
assessments for the subsequent projects (Supplementary Appendix J). This has been prepared 
by the Government in agreement with ADB, and in compliance with ADB’s Environment Policy 
(2002) and the Government’s environmental assessment regulations and guidelines.  
 
85.   A cumulative impact assessment has been undertaken for the Investment Program to 
examine the effects of this and the other donor’s road projects, as well as other initiatives being 
undertaken  in  a  number  of  key  sectors  (Supplementary  Appendix  K).  Valued  ecosystem 
components  have  been  identified  from  environment  subsectors  such  as  air  quality,  social 
development and poverty alleviation, agricultural development, land use and urban planning, 
tourism, and ecosystem health and biodiversity protection. The cumulative impact assessment 
is founded on comprehensive scoping to identify key valued ecosystem components and their 
indicators to ascertain the potential cumulative effects of multiple development activities. The 
cumulative impact assessment provides a prudent hedge against serious negative effects that 
could unnecessarily reduce the value of the road development. It also identifies, stimulates, or 
enhances cumulative benefits. 
 
C.  Assumptions and Potential Risks 
86.   The main potential risks to the Investment Program include lack of strict adherence to 
ADB’s Procurement Guidelines; start-up delays in implementation of the Investment Program 
particularly Project 1; and delays in preparatory works for the subsequent projects. Sound, 
timely, and cost-effective implementation of the Investment Program assumes a professional 
and competent project management function, an unaltered strategy and policy framework, and

23
continued institutional changes.  
 
87.   MOTC is to implement the financial management action plan and the anticorruption 
action plan to ensure that good governance is in place. Start-up delays risk will be mitigated by 
providing an international procurement specialist under an ADB technical assistance17 grant to 
help MOTC procure contractors, suppliers, and consultants until the PMC-ADB is selected. 
Detailed design works for the Investment Program is under way and financed under MOTC’s 
budget. Training on safeguards has been provided by ADB and the World Bank to national 
consultants preparing the detailed design. 
 
88.   Exogenous factors such as rising construction costs caused by fuel price increases may 
also affect the success of the Investment Program, especially with regard to the overall budget 
and current financing plan. Finally, and after construction, the success of the program will 
depend on how well and how frequently the assets are maintained. The introduction of best 
practice safety measures is also a matter for consideration. 
 
89.   Overall, the chances that implementation will be done on time, within budget and to 
international standards, are high. The project management team will be staffed with skilled 
personnel, national and international. An experienced professional with a record in project 
management and civil engineering will manage this team. The business processes and the 
operating procedures for awarding contracts and then managing them are reasonably well-
established and credible in Kazakhstan. It is also highly likely that the authorities will adhere to 
best practice when it comes to design and construction standards. Project management will be 
tightened and then monitored through the introduction of a high standard road construction 
management and information system. 
 
90.   The  Government  has  committed  to  the  strategy  and  policy  framework.  The  policy 
framework has all the right principles, including outsourcing to the private sector and regular 
road maintenance funding. The risk of a policy reversal is low. The same applies to the roles 
and functions of key institutions. MOTC has been restructured and given more of a regulatory 
and supervision mandate. It is unlikely that this institution will be reconverted to operate the 
construction and operation of the entire road network on its own. Maintenance remains in public 
hands. One of the key reforms includes the possible reintroduction of a road maintenance fund. 
This would assure continuity and stability with regard to the financing plan after the construction 
phase.  
 
91.   The  Government  is  also  assumed  to  continue  improving  cross-border  policies  and 
facilities,  and  sustaining  policies  conducive  to  economic  growth  and  regional  integration. 
Training will be given under Project 1 to take care of capacity building needs.

A.  Introduction 
1.   The economy of Kazakhstan has grown rapidly because of increased prices on its 
leading exports such as oil, metals, and grain. Gross domestic product (GDP) growth has 
reached about 10.6% annually since 2001.1 This growth is expected to continue, leading to an 
increase in road freight transport (in ton-kilometers) of about 10% per year and a rise in the 
number of vehicles of about 5% per year.2 The motorization level of about 100 cars per 1,000 
population is relatively high in the region but low by the European standard of above 300 cars 
per 1,000 inhabitants.3 
 
2.   Kazakhstan’s vast territory, low population density, mineral resources scattered across 
the country, and location between Europe and Asia make it one of the world’s most cargo-
intensive systems. This results in high dependency on the transport system.  
 
3.   Roads are a key element of Kazakhstan’s transport system, playing an important role in 
providing access to rural areas, and facilitating transit traffic and in-country transport movement. 
However, much of the road network is in poor condition—about 40% of the republican (national) 
roads requires major rehabilitation and proper maintenance. Moreover, the feeder road network 
serving rural population is not fully developed; and is characterized by poor conditions and a low 
service level, especially during wintertime. This results in high cost of goods—the transport cost 
component is about 10% of the cargo value, which is far above the average of about 4% in 
developed economies (footnote 1). Despite the high costs, the overall domestic transit volume 
(in tons) has grown rapidly, with annual growth of about 10%. A problem tree analysis is in 
Figure A2.

1.  Strategic Objective 
17.   Kazakhstan has put together a strategy or road map to develop the transport sector over 
the medium term. This covers all modes of transport, including national highways, as well as 
provincial  and  rural  roads.  The  strategy  recognizes  the  need  for  new  assets  (to  increase

improve quality). The 2006–2015 Transport Strategy outlines transport sector policies and key 
strategic directions. The main policy objective is to achieve (i) an accessible and affordable 
transport system, (ii) a safe and environmentally friendly transport system, (iii) an integrated 
transport system, (iv) self-recovery investment and operation, and (v) private sector-driven 
transport service provision.

contracted works, and has established a quality control unit. Routine maintenance and repair

3.  Challenges 
23.   Road  Condition  and  Maintenance.  While  the  republican  road  network  has  good 
coverage,  there  are  missing  links  and  the  rural  road  network  does  not  provide  many 
communities with reliable year-round road access.5 Significant sections of the republican road 
network are in poor condition. MOTC aims to achieve about 86% of republican roads and 70% 
of local roads in good condition by 2013 from 62% (republican roads) and 51% (local roads) in 
2006.  
 
24.   The  roads  performance  has  not  been  up  to  international  standards,  with  major 
investment in road rehabilitation and reconstruction being required before their lifetime period 
end. The level and frequency of reinvestment in the network in Kazakhstan is therefore very 
high, at $42,000 per km/year for the republican roads in the RDP.  
 
25.   Road Funding. The investment need for road asset preservation and maintenance is 
high. Only 40% of the republican roads are asphalt-based. Missing links also need to be 
constructed.  Funds  for  road  maintenance  have  increased  under  the  RDP  but  are  still  not 
sufficient. Road maintenance and repairs have been underfunded for some years, but have 
increased significantly in the last few years with the average allocation for routine maintenance 
and repairs (including winter maintenance) of about $2,000/km in 2008—about 50% less than 
the Canadian standard for road maintenance. Expenditure on periodic and routine maintenance 
is well below the level necessary for long-term network sustainability, and presently only makes 
up 7% of the budget indicated in the RDP.  
 
26.   The RDP is still dominated by road reconstruction, rehabilitation, and repairs. There are 
two main sources of funding for the road sector: (i) public sector budget and borrowings, and (ii) 
private sector sources. Government budget constraints are particularly critical. Funding for the 
road budget comes from the national budget rather than a specific road fund, although such a 
fund did exist some years ago, and the expenditure gathering mechanisms from that fund still 
exist. However, the revenue is managed by the Ministry of Finance. Private investment in road 
infrastructure  could  potentially  be  promoted  if  the  legislative  and  regulatory  framework  is 
improved.

27.   Road Safety. While the available data indicates that the road situation improved slightly 
in 2007, the number of people killed exceeded 2,000 with a further about 4,700 injured. A fatality 
rate of 18 per 100,000 inhabitants was reported in 2004, which was slightly above the regional 
average and growing at that time at a rate of more than 10% per annum. The number of people

accidents have only been increasing at around 10% per annum. This suggests that the severity 
of  accidents  is  increasing  at  a  rate  higher  than  the  fatality  rate  (about  15  per  100,000 
inhabitants) in the eastern European countries (footnote 3).  
 
28.   Road safety seems to be downplayed in the RDP even though the fatality accident rate 
is one of the highest in the region. Speeding is a key factor in road accidents. Inadequate 
passing opportunities caused by poor sight distances, especially in undulating terrain and poor 
shoulder conditions, make recovery impossible in many areas. The Ministry of Internal Security, 
which is responsible for addressing road accidents, analyzes accident data and attempts to 
identify causes. Past efforts to establish a high level Road Safety Commission have been 
resisted and such an organization does not exist at present. 
 
29.   The Ministry of Internal Affairs is the leading agency responsible, through the State 
Traffic  Police,  for  the  development  of  safety  standards,  rules,  and  regulations;  traffic 
management, surveillance, and enforcement; vehicle inspection; and accident data collection 
and analysis. MOTC is responsible for vehicle certification and developing relevant regulations. 
 
30.   Road design and operations is one of the causes of traffic accidents. Limited sight 
distance does not meet the international standard in some places. Road signage is generally 
inadequate. The ability of the authority to handle traffic accidents is inadequate. While the Police 
seem to have implemented a program of speed enforcement on some roads, this is limited to 
settlements. More effort on road safety is clearly required, especially in interurban roads.  
 
31.   Transit Traffic and Border Crossing. Geographically, the main transport routes in 
Kazakhstan are toward the Russian Federation, Europe, and Central Asia. The main road 
transit routes are to the Russian Federation and Central Asia while those destined for Europe 
and Asia account for less than 5% of the total road transit traffic. A total of 24,000 commercial 
transit vehicles, including large buses and medium to large trucks, crossed Kazakhstan in 2007 
(excluding trucks registered in Kazakhstan). A total of about 350,000 ton transit traffic was 
estimated in 2005, which is much lower than its capacity because of deteriorating infrastructure 
and  cross-border  impediments.  Cross-border  issues  include  unreasonable  delays  and 
complicated procedures in customs and frontier inspection, contradictions between transport 
legislation and internationals standards, and a lack of international treaties of transit and traffic 
regulation. Although there have been improvements and there are ongoing negotiations on 
transit and trade facilitation, border crossing continues to be time–consuming, with long delays 
at borders as loads are inspected and adjusted to accommodate legal limits.  
 
32.   Road Operations. High fatality rates, truck overloading, and low revenues from transit 
charges  have  been  partly  due  to  an  inadequate  road  operations  and  traffic  management 
system. Road operations and traffic management require reliable and accurate data about all 
aspects of the road network. An advance information system could be applied to include axle 
load monitoring and control facilities, road weather information systems, highways advisory 
radio and electronic signs, and traffic recording equipment. Such a system would provide data 
required by maintenance managers to make the right winter maintenance decisions to ensure 
that  road  restrictions  are  minimized  and  costs  are  low,  and  to  inform  road  users  of  road 
conditions in a timely manner.

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Trade Forecast 
1.   The majority of trade in the region runs from east to west through Kazakhstan. Hence, to 
explore the corridor's potential requires an understanding on the cargo types, major partners, 
and transportation modes. Kazakhstan's largest trade partners are the People’s Republic of 
China (PRC), Europe, and the Russian Federation while smaller countries in the region such as 
Uzbekistan and the Kyrgyz Republic comprise a relatively small amount in trade value, despite 
contributing significantly in trade volumes (tons).  
 
2.   In general, the region is stable and Kazakhstan enjoys good relations with its neighbors. 
The following trends are expected: 
 
(i)  The freight movement between the PRC, Central Asian countries, and ultimately 
Iran, is expected to fulfill one of the main growth drivers of the corridor, in 
particular in the Khorgos–Almaty–Shymkent segments. The corridor is expected 
to attract a significant market share for freight of consumer and manufactured 
goods but not raw materials, even though the service level provided by the 
Trans-Asian Railway is still low. This is partly dependent on the realization of a 
major upgrade program of road infrastructure in the Central Asian countries. 
 
(ii)  The  emerging  role  of  the  PRC  as  a  global  manufacturer  and  exporter  of 
consumer goods, which are more sensitive to door-to-door distribution and in 
time shipment, will contribute to the fulfillment of the corridor as a west PRC–
west Europe link. This is due to the competitive advantage of the corridor for this 
type of cargo, especially from the western PRC. Production from the eastern 
PRC will continue to be transported by ship or rail because of distance. For other 
types of trade, such as energy and raw materials, the corridor is much less 
attractive.  
 
(iii)  Trade  between  the  PRC  and  Kazakhstan  is  expected  to  grow  above  the 
projections for PRC’s trade growth. This is due to high yield development plans 
for  industry  in  western  PRC.  However,  freight  attracted  by  the  corridor  is 
dependent  mainly  on  competition  from  the  (less  quality)  railway  network. 
Improving the border crossing process and implementing the Free Trade Zone 
may  increase  the  market  share  of  roads  versus  trains  for  small  distance 
consumer goods freight shipment (i.e., Almaty). 
 
(iv)  Trade between the Russian Federation and Kazakhstan is expected to grow 
substantially. However, the majority of the trade is energy and raw materials, 
which the corridor will not attract. This is due to the development plans of natural 
gas and oil pipelines. Because of this and the fact that the Russian Federation 
trades less of other types of cargo, it is expected that the level of freight flows by 
roads in general and through the corridor will not increase. For most of the freight 
that  will  be  transferred  via  road  between  these  two  countries,  there  is  little 
substitution to the corridor because of its superiority in connecting the most 
populated  and  industrial  regions  of  the  country.  Obviously,  freight  from  the 
Astana region will not utilize the corridor.

D.  Economic Analysis Approach 
10.   Economic analysis was carried out comparing with- and without-Investment Program 
scenarios.  The  base  case  reflects  expected  conditions  in  the  absence  of  the  Investment 
Program, with maintenance sufficient only to hold the road in its present condition. The project 
case  involves  initial  investment  followed  by  routine  and  periodic  maintenance,  but  with 
expenditure and frequency of periodic maintenance economically optimum for predicted road 
conditions and traffic flows. 
 
11.   The analysis was conducted by using the Highway Development Model 4. It predicts 
average  travel  speed,  pavement  roughness,  agency  costs,  and  road  user  costs.  It  also 
calculates the economic viability of road links. All costs and benefits are expressed in mid-2007 
prices.  
 
12.   Economic  analysis  was  conducted  using  the  border  price  numeraire.  A  standard 
conversion factor for non-tradable goods was applied to calculate the economic price of non-
tradable goods. The shadow wage rates for skilled and unskilled labor were estimated by 
comparing  the  average  labor  wage  in  the  region  and  the  project  labor  wage,  taking  into 
consideration the existing unemployment rate. The shadow wage rates for skilled and unskilled 
labor were adjusted by using a standard conversion factor. The net present value at a 12% 
discount factor and the economic internal rate of return (EIRR) were calculated to evaluate the 
economic viability of the Investment Program. 
 
13.   The  economic  costs  were  estimated  based  on  financial  costs,  including  physical 
contingencies.  Price  escalation  contingencies,  interest  during  construction,  and  taxes  were 
excluded. Financial costs were converted into economic costs using specific conversion factors 
of 0.92 for road construction and 0.80 for road maintenance.  
 
14.   A single stage of road development for the Investment Program is envisaged. The initial 
investment for civil works will be implemented over a 3-year period from mid-2009 to 2012. A 
residual value at the end of the evaluation period is estimated at 35% of the initial investment.

15.   The Investment Program’s primary economic benefits are vehicle operating cost (VOC) 
savings and travel time savings. Economic benefits to generated domestic traffic are calculated 
as  half of  the  difference  in  unit  VOCs  in  with-  and  without-Investment  Program  scenarios 
multiplied by generated traffic volumes, in accordance with the “rule of the half.”1  
 
16.   Economic benefits from travel time savings to normal and diverted traffic are calculated 
similarly, as the difference in unit travel time under with- and without-Investment Program 
scenarios multiplied by traffic volumes and the value of time. The rule of the half applies 
similarly to generated traffic.

II.  SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
 
A.  Findings of Social Analysis  
 
Zhambyl Oblast is considered one of the less developed parts of Kazakhstan. Population is centered along the rivers 
and near the foothills; the northern area is desert. This is principally a region of irrigated agriculture—vegetables, 
wine, cotton, sugar beet, and rice. Agriculture spurred intensive development of the food and light industries. There 
are also phosphate mining, metallurgy, mechanical engineering, oil production, and refinery industries2 in the oblast 
as well. 
 
Zhambyl Oblast covers 144,300 km2. The oblast center is Taraz, once a main stop on the Silk Road, with the 
population of 336,100 (34% of the total oblast population). There are 10 raions (districts), 12 urban settlements, and 
367 villages in the oblast. Most of the villages and urban settlements were constructed as part of the state and 
collective farm structure. Statistically, Zhambyl oblast has an employment level of 90% (448,000), which is close to 
the national average employment of 92%. 
 
Unemployment rates vary significantly—as much as 9.5%—from one raion to another. The highest unemployment 
rates are in the town of Taraz (14.3%), Mojynkum raion (13.2%), and Turara Ryskulova raion (11.7%). The lowest 
unemployment rates are in Sarysuy (4.8%), Korday (5.0%), and Shu (6.8%) raion. In 2004, 18.3% of the Zhambyl 
population was below the minimum subsistence level, 14.6% in urban areas and 21.2% in rural areas. Household 
expenditures averaged 46% for food, 31% for nonfood items, and 23% for services.5 Monthly average wages in the 
oblast region are 66% of the national average, and household consumption is 71% of the national average.3 
 
Project 1 includes two distinct types of terrain and settlement. Section 3 (Km 404 – 483) goes east from Taraz, the 
oblast center and a former stop on the Silk Road, passing through a desert area with little inhabitation and wide vistas 
of the mountains to the south and the steppes to the north. The terrain is flat and occasionally rolling segment of the 
road near Taraz has a double carriageway; the remainder is a two-lane road. There are no visible encroachments on 
the right of way (ROW) and the road traverses few villages. In contrast, section 6 (Km 214 – 260) is in a more 
densely populated area and characterized by more intensive and varied agriculture. Compared to section 3, section 6 
has large tracts lined with trees that were undoubtedly planted as windbreak. The terrain is flat and the road is 
straight, with gentle curves as it winds through the countryside.  
 
Project 1 will transform the segment into a category 1 highway staying within the existing ROW, with little visible 
impact. Reconstruction of section 3 will not change local transportation access or traffic patterns, although it is 
expected to increase transit traffic significantly once work on the whole corridor is completed. Small villages are 
frequent in section 6, especially compared to section 3, all of which are typical of collective and state farm settlements 
in southern Kazakhstan. Also consistent with other areas, village settlements respect the highway ROWs and there 
are no visible signs of encroachment by permanent structures. The reconstruction in section 6 will leave the road as a 
category 2 highway, fully within the existing ROW, so there should be no need for permanent land acquisition or 
relocation on temporary structures. Highway improvement will not materially change local transportation access or 
traffic patterns. 
 
The investment does not raise any social issues that require additional investigation prior to program implementation. 
The challenges and opportunities are clear and simple, and no new social risks are likely to emerge. Consequently, 
rather  than  recommend  more  in-depth  analysis  during  program  preparation,  this  poverty  and  social  analysis 
recommends that a social assessment be undertaken and used for three purposes: (i) inform people about the 
Investment Program and expected schedule, (ii) identify local concerns that have not emerged, and (iii) establish a 
socioeconomic baseline for eventual use in program monitoring and impact evaluation.   
 
Highway construction and the development of long-term transit routes have promoted the transmission and spread of 
HIV in many areas. In Kazakhstan overall, the HIV infection rate of women is increasing and the prevalence of 
infection among drug users is declining,4 suggesting that attention should be given to transit routes as points of 
transmission. The Investment Program will conduct public information on HIV transmission and initiate a needle 
exchange program at one site. The Investment Program is not likely to affect current trafficking patterns materially, as 
the investments will not remove any significant transit barriers. However, once work on the full corridor including 
Zhambyl Oblast is completed. , the improved corridor may be seen by both human and drug traffickers as an 
attractive alternative to the prevailing south–north route.

8.   Institutional Responsibilities. The Committee of Roads through a project director has 
the overall responsibility for LAR preparation, implementation, and financing with the assistance 
of a project management consultant (PMC). At the PMC, LAR tasks will be handled by a LAR 
consultant. The PMC will be assisted by a construction supervision team and by nongovernment 
organizations or impact assessment/valuation consultants hired for impact surveys/monitoring 
assistance. The PMC will coordinate with raion governments that have jurisdiction over land 
administration/valuation.  
 
9.   The LARPs will be mostly implemented by raion-level officials, with the support of the 
oblast administration, civil works contractors, and officials of local self-government. Evaluation 
and compensation are managed  by a raion-level commission established for the purpose, 
including staff of the raion administration and officials representing different relevant offices, 
such as agriculture, forestry, roads, land resource management, and registration.   
 
10.   Disclosure/Public  Consultation. The consultation process begins when the akimat 
notifies  potential  affected  persons  that  their  lands  may  be  subject to  being  reserved.  The 
valuation process also involves direct consultation with affected persons and is expected to 
result in satisfactory agreements. Affected persons can discuss their concerns with officials and, 
if dissatisfied, can appeal to the court for a binding valuation.

languages will be disclosed on the project website, MOTC website, at the offices of the Oblast

12.   Grievance  Procedures.  All  project-related  complaints  will  be  handled  through LAR 
grievance mechanisms that follow the existing pattern and will be described in the project’s 
information brochures and posted in local offices: (i) affected persons take their complaints to 
the head of local self-government, who registers the complaint and attempts to resolve it. If the 
complaint is not resolved in 1 week, it is passed to the raion level; (ii) a designated person in the 
raion administration receives the complaint, registers it, and attempts to resolve it. If there is no 
resolution in 2 weeks, it is passed to the oblast level; and (iii) a designated person in the oblast 
administration receives the complaint and attempts to resolve it. If there is no resolution within 
2 weeks, it is passed to project management for resolution on a priority basis.4 If again after this 
last step, no solution is found, the affected persons can bring their case to the appropriate court 
of law.  
 
13.   Alternatively, persons who feel that their grievances are not given adequate attention 
can contact project management. The monitoring and evaluation officer will acknowledge and 
register such complaints and seek resolution, reporting to the complainant on a weekly basis.  
 
14.   Monitoring and Evaluation. LAR will be monitored internally and externally. Internal 
monitoring will be carried out by the raion administration, which will report to the EA on a 
monthly basis. The work will be overseen by the project management team LAR specialist.    
 
15.   The Investment Program will hire an external monitoring agency, which will carry out an 
independent assessment of the resettlement process and outcomes to be submitted every 
6 months  to  the  EA  and  ADB.  The  external  monitoring  agency  will  assess  whether 
implementation complies with provisions of the resettlement plan, if the livelihoods of affected 
peoples have been restored, and whether or not any unintended or unanticipated resettlement 
impacts have occurred. 
 
16.   Finances  and  Schedules. The cost of administrative oversight and monitoring and 
evaluation activities will be included in the project budget and reflected in the LARP budget.
